Paytm pulls back to loans below 50,000 rupees; says it is ultra conservative on the space.

The story so far — the RBI spent about a year giving veiled warnings on personal loans, signalling growth was too rapid.

Industry ignored said we see no issues. Credit appraisal methods have evolved. We see cash flows. All is well. 

At last policy, RBI goes further says engaging with some lenders, some segments of personal loans a concern. Most in the industry still maintained its BAU.

It become clear the issue was in sub-50,000 loans. Some bureau data started to emerge to show that there is loan stacking / rise in delinquencies.

RBI raises risk weights across personal loans.

Now, after months of denying there was an issue, the pull-back from the industry begins.

The pull-back, if too sudden, will actually only worsen the problem or at least quicken the process of the problem showing up.

But that’s the way it goes.

? Paytm' 20% fall, story behind it. Read along. 
Paytm to clamp down its BNPL business after increased scrutiny by RBI on BNPL type lending. 
• RBI brought restrictions on loading credit lines onto prepaid instruments like wallets and prepaid cards. 
• Capital adequacy requirements are raised to 15%(min) so BNPL companies can have sufficient capital reserves to absorb potential losses and maintain financial stability.
• Others requirements like CDD and KYC, limit restriction, data sharing with credit bureaus, increased reporting requirements to have more transparency and restrictions on partnerships are also on place.
? Major chunk of Paytm's loan disbursement business comes from BNPL (almost 40-45%) so IMV it will have a short term impact on Paytm's business though there increased focus on big ticket lending will offset it to some extent but will take some time. 
?I think their clamping BNPL business and shifting to big ticket stable lending is a blessing in disguise and a welcome step towards becoming a matured lender. (Risk profile and margin is much better in big ticket lending) so current volatility may remain but it is a step in the right direction. #Paytm #upi #StocksToBuy #StockMarket #zerodha #BRC20 #stockstowatch #stockmarkets #GIFTNIFTY #Nifty #NiftyFifty #TradingView #investing #AdaniGroup

PayTM Down 20% today

Hits the lower circuit (and then recovers) on their plans to cut back on Small Loans

MOSL Report said - 

- will scale down loans with ticket sizes below Rs. 50k and focus on larger ticket sizes. This will lead to a 50% decline in current disbursement run rate, from Rs. 60bn to Rs. 45bn per month.
- Postpaid loan product will not be shut down, but disbursements will decrease by 40-50%.
- Paytm adds average 0.35m-0.4m customers every quarter, which is now expected to come down by 50%.

PayTM Concall - 

- The share of below-INR50k personal loans is negligible in its overall portfolio. Personal loans only form 4%, down from 7-9% previously.
- In >50k BNPL, the bureau report shows some caution. High-quality customers will still get this service, but only some cohorts of customers are now excludedfrom accessing BNPL loans

No reco.

PayTm's loan business was a big contributor towards its 41% YOY quarterly revenue growth?

The company COO believes that it'll impact their postpaid product's volume by 40-50% and revenue dip of 15-20% QoQ?

Why is it pulling brakes on this business?? Here's why ?

1?? Business Model

Paytm currently has seven non-bank finance companies (NBFCs) as lending partners. It has the distribution (people using its app) and NBFCs have the license and capital.

So, in exchange of getting people who take loans from banks via PayTm, NBFCs pay PayTm a commission as %age of loans disbursed.

2?? Why this decision?

The RBI recently increased the risk weights on personal loans. The new regulations required the banks to have more capital for than before to issue personal loans. But why?

It was because of the low wage growth in the economy, rising unemployment rate which increased the risk of defaults by people availing personal loans.

NBFC partners of PayTm would have been reluctant to issue loans in this category after the regulators action and thus, this action by PayTm.

3?? Impact on PayTm

Bhavesh Gupta, President & COO at Paytm said that will lead to a near 40%-50% drop in the volume of loans Paytm issues through its post-paid product, but will have a minimal impact on revenue growth.

Paytm's post-paid loans accounted for about 56% of total loans in the July-September quarter, per company data.

"We expect a negative impact of about 15% quarter-on-quarter on the (total) value of loans distributed by Paytm ... but revenue impact should be much less, at around 5% QoQ," he said.

Sources used: Reuters, Company Data, RBI

I understand that this is short term pain for the long term gain of the economy. Bail-out packages for banks are far more costly for the country than aggressively advancing loans.

What is your view on this? Tell me in the comments.

Paytm's Share Price Collapse

Paytm’s share price tanked yesterday. If you bought it in the IPO and were brave enough to hold it, you are now down 70%. That is still better than where the stock was just four months after it listed. But it is worrying if you bought it late in October. From its peak on 23rd of October, the stock is down one-third of its value. 
 
In fact, the Paytm stock did pretty well this year, going up by almost 80% between March and October. That was because, its new business model – of giving loans small ticket loans through the Buy Now Pay Later (BNPL) model – had started to show traction. This boosted the stock which had been written off after UPI more or less destroyed its wallet business. 
 
The BNPL model was especially important because it delivered on its promise of being a growth company. Those who followed Paytm’s listing would remember what the legendary valuation guru Aswath Damodaran had said about the company. Pointing to the fact that its revenues were not growing at the same pace as its users, Damodaran came to the “cynical conclusion that the company is adding new services and giving them away for nothing (or close to it) to pad its user/transaction numbers.”
 
 Damodaran was looking at two key metrices to value Paytm, especially since it was a loss making ‘growth company’ – Revenue growth and the Take Rate, or revenues as a percentage of the total value of transactions (since Paytm got only a fraction of the gross value of the transactions made on its platform). 
 
At that time Paytm’s revenues had remained stagnant for four years, while its take rate had halved from 1.6% to 0.8%. Also, it was nowhere close to breaking even. Since then, Paytm’s revenues have nearly tripled in two years (2020-21 to 2022-23) and its take rate has risen by 2.5 times to 0.2%. This massive revenue growth has been achieved by losing just an additional Rs.140 crore, which isn’t a lot for such a big growth company. 
 
Much of this recovery was driven by small personal loans and the BNPL business. And a big part of this loan business were small ticket loans. Now that the RBI has tightened norms for such loans, Paytm has announced that it will cut back on its BNPL business by half. Brokerages have reacted to this by cutting their revenue and operating profit estimates sharply by 12-15%. 
 
Interestingly, despite cutting their estimates and the Target Price (the price at which it is believed to be fairly valued), most brokerages still believe Paytm is worth buying (or at least holding) at current prices. Motilal Oswal’s latest Target Price, released two days ago, is Rs.1,025. Jeffries has a target price of Rs.1,050, post its earnings estimate downgrade. Morgan Stanley believes Paytm is fairly valued now at Rs.830, while Goldman Sachs has revised its Target Price down to Rs.840.

If these brokerages are to be believed, there's still value in the Paytm stock at these levels. But believe them at your own risk!

P.S. This post is just an explanation and not an advisory

What's up with #Paytm ?

Paytm CRASHED 20% intraday yesterday after the company said it would pull back on disbursing loans worth below Rs 50,000. Several brokerage firms including Jefferies and Goldman Sachs downgraded the stock and SLASHED their target prices. Experts say it could see a 40% hit on loan volumes and a 5% hit on top line growth. Overall, a big yikes situation. ?

But how did we get here? For over a year, the RBI low-key warned banks about unsecured personal loans growth. The lenders themselves went on the defensive and said that it was all OK. In June, experts started flagging repayment delays and a growing share of ‘subprime customers’ (bad borrowers) in the small-ticket personal loan segment. ?

Then bang. In November, the RBI cracked the whip and effectively made it more expensive for banks (and loan-disbursing aggregators like Paytm) to give out unsecured personal loans. After this, the pullback FINALLY began with Paytm execs saying yesterday that they would be “ultra-conservative” in the sub-Rs 50k segment. ?

FYI – this segment accounts for almost 50% of Paytm’s ‘buy now, pay later’ (BNPL) loans and around 38% of its total loan biz. That’s HUGE! These loans are lucrative from a bottom line perspective but don’t add too much to the top line since they are small-ticket-sized. Dolat Capital says revenue impact will be around 5% QoQ. ?

Big Picture: The loan biz was widely seen as a huge positive for Paytm, something that helped put it on the path to profitability. This is why analysts are undertaking huge target price cuts; Goldman Sachs (Rs 1,250 ? Rs 840), and JP Morgan (Rs 1,200 ? Rs 900). Let’s see how this pans out in the long term. ??

#FitnessDiaries

***How fat loss works:***

Your Paytm wallet had 1000 bucks in the morning & you spent 500 bucks during the day; what are you left with, 500 bucks right??

Now suppose, someone sent you 500 bucks on your Paytm wallet. Damn.. you ended up with 1000 bucks despite having spent 500 bucks in the day.

Okay, that's just an analogy for you all.

Replace the money with the fat stored in the fat cells of your body and suddenly, you would realise that the amount received in the wallet from whatever source, means, the fat you lost from the cells is suddenly replenished.

The same happens when you don't adhere to your diet properly. Point to be driven home is, fat burning and fat loss are not the same.

You may burn a lot of fat during a given phase of time due to eating less, not eating or doing a strenuous physical activity (like the so called fat burning exercises). However, the lost fat could easily be replenished in no time, if your diet isn't on point.

Fat loss is the aggregate of cumulative fat burning phases over a period of time. This can happen only when you follow an approach which leads to build up of a negative energy balance over a period of time.

It's important to focus on the overall picture and not just click bait things like fat burning exercises or fat burning diet patterns. Plus, you gotta keep following the method to continue dropping fat or to continue keeping it off too. 

Hence, focus on sustainable methods which tick all the boxes rather than using short term quick fix methods which actually don't fix anything.

Anyone can be wrong about stock picks. But, the argument that PayTM will replace banks is a garbage argument. 

Here are the reasons: 

[1] It is incredibly difficult to get a banking licence in India. Banks in India are tightly regulated. 

 FinTechs are not banks, they typically work with traditional banks to offer an additional of service. In most cases, these are conveniences. 

** What type of licence PayTM has, I have explained in the next tweet 

[2] FinTech's existence depends on banks. Not the other way round. 

[3] When you have physical branches, there is a level of trust you enjoy. 

Even the biggest D2C firms (a less trust oriented business compared to finance) have started to realise this. 

From being completely online, they are now moving to 'omni-channels'. And, creating physical branches. 

Most importantly, everything that happens in the WEST, does not apply to INDIA. 

There is high trust deficit in a market like India. 

And, if this is the level of idiotic advice you are getting from SEBI registered guys, maybe we should have better filtering mechanism.

I personally find @Paytm as one of the smoothest UPI apps and it is my daily driver. Here's some feedback as a long-time user:

1. Bring "UPI and Payment Settings" from the side profile menu to the home screen. 

2. Too many buttons on the home screen. Each of the icons in this screenshot could have been a single button. We know you have to market your product, but too much clutter makes the app look cheap. Cred used to be a good example of balancing design and marketing. 

3. Please separate online gaming as an app. Seeing a "teen patti" ad on top of my homescreen every time I open Paytm doesn't really help build brand credibility. You cannot have Paytm Money and Online Poker side by side and expect people to make serious investments. 

4. You may consider a separate app for other segments as well. I have never booked a flight or hotel on Paytm. But "Paytm Travels" with a full range of holiday options and hotel searches? I would give that a try! Indian consumers prefer separate quality apps instead of one mediocre super-app. Don't know why companies have such a hard time understanding this. 

5. Cashback points have been diluted to the point they are merely an advertising gimmick. Indian users have accepted that apps cannot keep giving cashbacks forever. People use Google Pay despite zero cashbacks. You don't need to insult them by throwing ads in the name of cashbacks. 

6. Design your own card feature for Paytm debit and credit cards (most other banks offer this). 

7. "AI led customer care" is just another phrase for "we have bots that will give generic auto replies and not solve any problem". I would rather prefer a busy helpline number with an actual person on the other end, given I am using the app for my financial transactions.

2023: My Read of the Top 10 Trends 

1) Year of net job losses in the Tech and Startup industry

After a massive indulgence in hiring in 2021-22, almost all tech players and startups downsized. These layoffs started with Facebook and ended with Paytm. There is some more pain yet to come. 

2) Year of Generative AI

Open AI became mainstream despite its board room theatrics. Nvidia became a Trillion $ company while Open AI is looking to do a new funding round at $100B. 

We are in the era of AI and AI is eating the world. 

3) IPOs: 

Successful IPO of MamaEarth has spread cheer and hope amongst many in the pipeline. Hammered tech stocks like Zomato bounced back in 2023. 

4) Profits over Growth: 

A New Paradigm has emerged in the startup ecosystem. Almost all Startups put the brakes on growth and focused on profitability. 

5) Ukraine —> Gaza 

War action moved from Ukraine to Gaza…humanity reached a new low and faces extreme polarization. 

Oil and Food prices remained high through out the year as a result of these two wars. 

6) Year of Political consolidation for BJP in India 

Despite winning Karnataka, Telangana, & HP, Congress doesn’t feel like a strong challenge to BJP in 2024, which gained Chhattisgarh, Rajasthan and MP. 

7) Interest Rates have peaked globally and it seems that these will move downwards from this historic peak.

This has created a late burst in stock markets. 

8) Pollution Peak

Almost whole of North India is now in the severe grip of endemic pollution…Govts in various states and centre continue to bicker while masses continue to suffer endlessly. 

9) Big Sports is Big Business 

Despite winning 10 straight games in the Cricket World Cup, Indian team faltered in the finals. IPL reached new heights in team and players valuations. 

Soccer World Cup: Argentina won the World Cup and the legend of Messi grew multifold. 

Saudi Arabia launched its own soccer league and has poured billions to attracting mega stars (like Ronaldo) from major European soccer leagues. 

10) US, China and India

Dollar continues to be the global currency of trade and business. There is no competition in sight despite some noises made in 2023 by China and Russia. 

2nd placed Chinese economy slowed down its growth, while 5th place Indian economy has grown strongly.

They have to go back to their parents/wife/kids/family and explain: why they are NOT going to office anymore. 

These are brutal conversations to have. This scars them for life. 

I'm no one to preach how businesses should run. 

But, when firing in 1000s looks like an everyday event, jobs stop meaning anything, honestly.

It's electric bike is expected by FY25 and god knows when the car will be released. Why isn't the 2W biz profitable at unit level ? What capex is being planned if the demand is slowing down? I think it's just awful that our Indian startups kept overhiring and are now laying off people citing all sorts of excuses. 

The AI excuse of Paytm is just ridiculous unless ChatGPT has replaced their EAs' EAs' EAs. I can't imagine any company in India is actually using AI right now except for automating support which was there even earlier (and you don't really need AI for that). They are probably laying off people because everyone overhired in the first place. 

Unfortunately, these "AI excuses" just lead to doom and gloom with headlines like "AI is here for your jobs: Paytm lays off 1,000 workers amid automation push". No, AI is not coming for your jobs. AI is a tool you use to do your job faster and better. AI may only lead to less freelancing for quick jobs which solopreuners can manage on their own instead of going on fiverr.

Incidentally, even we (misguidedly but the buck stops with me) went on a hiring spree after funding but we were still operating with the mindset of a MSME as our leaders were not from the startup world and more from the conventional business world. Hence, when times became tough for us, people left on their own and with enough goodwill on both sides as we kept everyone in the company informed at all times about the runway and the then prospects (during the lockdowns).
